perturbation.original_text: Beginning on the date you begin operations under this Agreement, which is agreed to be the date set out in the Declarations Page (the "Commencement Date"), we will remit to you Net Revenues on a monthly basis. As used in this Agreement:
perturbation.changed_text: Beginning on the date you begin operations under this Agreement, which is agreed to be the date set out in the Declarations Page (the "Commencement Date"), we will remit to you Net Revenues on a monthly basis. However, Net Revenues may be remitted quarterly based on a separate addendum to this agreement. As used in this Agreement:
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an in-text contradiction by stating that Net Revenues will be remitted monthly and also potentially quarterly. This creates ambiguity and uncertainty, which section should be enforced and disrupts the consistency of the payment terms.

perturbation.original_text: 4.5 Late Payment. If we do not (or an applicable marketing fund does not) receive any payment due under this Agreement on or before the due date, then that amount will be deemed overdue. If any payment is overdue, then you agree to pay us, in addition to the overdue amount, interest on the overdue amount from the date it was due until paid, at the rate of eighteen percent (18%) per annum (but not more than the maximum rate permitted by law, if any such maximum rate applies). Our entitlement to such interest will be in addition to any other remedies we may have. Any report that we do not receive on or before the due date will also be deemed overdue.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.5 Late Payment. If we do not (or an applicable marketing fund does not) receive any payment due under this Agreement on or before the due date, then that amount will be deemed overdue. If any payment is overdue, then you agree to pay us, in addition to the overdue amount, interest on the overdue amount from the date it was due until paid, at the rate of eighteen percent (18%) per annum (but not more than the maximum rate permitted by law, if any such maximum rate applies). However, at our sole discretion we may choose not to charge interest on late payments. Our entitlement to such interest will be in addition to any other remedies we may have. Any report that we do not receive on or before the due date will also be deemed overdue.
perturbation.explanation: By adding 'However, at our sole discretion we may choose not to charge interest on late payments', the clause becomes contradictory. The first half states that interest will be charged on overdue payments, and the second half makes it optional. This conflict creates uncertainty and potential for disputes.

perturbation.original_text: We have the right to adjust, for inflation, all fixed-dollar amounts under this Agreement (except for the Initial Franchise Fee) once a year to reflect changes in the Index from the year in which you signed this Agreement. For the purpose of this Section 4.8, the term "Index" means the Consumer Price Index (1982- 84=100; all items; CPI-U; all urban consumers) as published by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics ("BLS"). If the BLS no longer publishes the Index, then we will have the right to designate a reasonable alternative measure of inflation.
perturbation.changed_text: We have the right to adjust, for inflation, all fixed-dollar amounts under this Agreement (except for the Initial Franchise Fee) once a year to reflect changes in the Index from the year in which you signed this Agreement. However, fixed-dollar amounts will only be adjusted every three years, regardless of inflation. For the purpose of this Section 4.8, the term "Index" means the Consumer Price Index (1982- 84=100; all items; CPI-U; all urban consumers) as published by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics ("BLS"). If the BLS no longer publishes the Index, then we will have the right to designate a reasonable alternative measure of inflation.
perturbation.explanation: The modification presents a contradiction by saying that adjustments happen 'once a year' but 'fixed-dollar amounts will only be adjusted every three years'. This inconsistency makes it unclear which interval is applicable, making it uncertain when adjustments will occur.
